column4: Delta slashes 2018 forecast, quarterly profit drops
column5: July 12 (Reuters) - Delta Air Lines Inc reported a 13.6 percent drop in quarterly profit on Thursday as its operating expenses swelled due to a 38.8 percent jump in fuel costs.
column6: The No.2 U.S. carrier slashed its full-year earnings outlook to a range of $5.35 to $5.70 per share from $6.35 to $6.70 per share and said it expected its fuel bill in 2018 to surge by $2 billion.
column7: The company’s net income fell to $1.03 billion, or $1.47 per share, in the second quarter ended June 30, from $1.19 billion, or $1.62 per share, a year earlier.
column8: The total unit revenue - a measure which compares sales with flight capacity - increased 4.6 percent in the quarter, boosted by higher average fares.
column9: On an adjusted basis, the airline earned $1.77 per share.
column10: Delta’s total operating revenue rose 9.6 percent to $11.78 billion in the quarter. (Reporting by Arunima Banerjee in Bengaluru; Editing by Arun Koyyur)

column4: Delta Air CEO says higher jet fuel to add $2 billion to costs
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - Delta Air Lines DAL.N is expecting $2 billion in additional costs this year due to the swelling expense of jet fuel, Chief Executive Officer Ed Bastian said on Twitter on Wednesday.
column6: Earlier this month, Delta blamed a 50 percent annual rise in fuel costs for its decision to lower its second quarter profit forecast to between $1.65 and $1.75 per share from a previous estimate of up to $2 per share.
column7: The rising cost of jet fuel already weighed on U.S. airlines' earnings in the first quarter and prompted rival American Airlines AAL.O to cut its full-year profit forecast in April.
column8: Atlanta-based Delta and its competitors are hoping strong demand, higher ticket prices and benefits from reductions in the U.S. corporate tax rate will eventually offset the impact of higher fuel prices.
column9: Delta’s shares were down about 2 percent at $50.04 in afternoon trading, slightly underperforming a 1.5 percent decline on the Dow Jones U.S. Airlines Index .DJUSAR.

column4: Delta Air CEO says expects $2 bln in added costs on higher jet fuel expenses
column5: NEW YORK, June 27 (Reuters) - Delta Air Lines Chief Executive Officer Ed Bastian on Wednesday said the carrier is expecting $2 billion in additional costs this year as jet fuel expenses have swelled. (Reporting by Alana Wise, editing by G Crosse)

column4: KLM, Delta opposed to Capron as head of Air France KLM: media
column5: PARIS (Reuters) - KLM and Delta Airlines DAL.N have expressed their opposition toward possible plans to name Philippe Capron as the new head of Air France KLM AIRF.PA, BFM Business reported on Monday.
column6: KLM, the Dutch airline part of the overall Air France KLM group, and Delta Airlines - which has an 8.8 percent equity stake in the company - were concerned over Capron’s lack of experience in the aviation sector, added BFM Business.
column7: A spokeswoman for Air France KLM said the company had no comment to make on the matter.
column8: A source told Reuters last week that Capron, currently chief financial officer at French water utility company Veolia VIE.PA, was among the favorites to become the new CEO of Air France KLM.
column9: Over the weekend, French Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire had confirmed that Capron was “one candidate among several others” for the post of Air France KLM CEO.
column10: Air France-KLM’s former chief executive Jean-Marc Janaillac resigned last month after staff rejected a new pay offer.

column4: Bombardier to sell 20 regional jets with new cabin design to Delta
column5: (Reuters) - Canadian plane and train maker Bombardier Inc BBDb.TO said on Wednesday that Delta Air Lines Inc DAL.N has signed an agreement to buy 20 CRJ900 regional jets with its new Atmosphere cabin design.
column6: The airplanes, which Delta will take delivery of in late 2018, are valued at about $961 million based on the list price, Bombardier said.
column7: Delta Air Lines will be the first major airline to use Bombardier’s revamped CRJ planes with cabins that have bigger overhead storage bins, wider aisles and mood lighting.
column8: The Montreal-based planemaker has been investing in its CRJ planes, after it acknowledged that the line had been neglected as it focused more on its C-Series program.
column9: Late last year, Bombardier agreed to sell Airbus a 50.01 percent stake in its C-Series flagship commercial jet for a token fee of one Canadian dollar, after sluggish sales and low production rates pushed the program well over budget.
column10: Including the order from Delta, Bombardier has recorded firm orders for 1,953 CRJ Series aircraft, the company said.

column4: Bombardier to sell 20 aircraft to Delta Air Lines
column5: June 20 (Reuters) - Canadian plane and train maker Bombardier Inc said on Wednesday that Delta Air Lines Inc has signed a purchase agreement for 20 CRJ900 aircraft, in a deal valued at about $961 million.
column6: The airplanes, which Delta will take delivery in late 2018, will be the first to feature Bombardier’s new Atmosphère cabin design, Bombardier said. (Reporting by Karan Nagarkatti in Bengaluru; Editing by Shounak Dasgupta)

column4: Delta Air shares slip as rising fuel costs weigh on profits
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - Delta Air Lines DAL.N on Wednesday lowered its second quarter profit forecast due to rising fuel costs, and its shares fell as much as nearly 4 percent before trimming those losses.
column6: The Atlanta-based carrier said it now expects to earn between $1.65 and $1.75 per share, down from its earlier projection of up to $2 per share.
column7: Its pre-tax margin will now fall somewhere in the 13 percent to 14 percent range, from its prior view of between 14 percent and 16 percent, the carrier said in a Wednesday report.
column8: The airline's shares were down 1.5 percent at $53.83 after earlier falling as low as $52.63, extending about a 5 percent year-to-date loss. The Dow Jones U.S. Airlines Index .DJUSAR was down 0.5 percent and off nearly 12 percent for the year.
column9: Delta said jet fuel prices have risen some 50 percent since last year and about 12 percent since the beginning of the quarter.
column10: The rising cost of jet fuel is weighing on earnings across the U.S. sector, cutting into summer profits and prompting air fare increases.
column11: Delta and its competitors are hoping strong demand, higher ticket prices and benefits from reductions in the U.S. corporate tax rate will eventually offset the impact of higher fuel prices. Rival American Airlines AAL.O cut its profit forecast in April, also citing higher fuel costs.

column4: Barron's: Delta, Goodyear stock have more upside than prices suggest
column5: (Reuters) - Delta Air Lines, Goodyear Tire & Rubber and Lincoln National Corp may have more upside than their discounted share prices suggest, Barron’s reported.
column6: The newspaper reviewed stocks trading at no more than about half the valuation of the Standard & Poor’s 500 index - which recently approached 17 times forward earning estimates - and spotlighted those not facing “obvious threats of structural decline” or “hitting cyclical peaks.”
column7: Delta DAL.N, which closed at $55.40 per share on Friday, is at 8.6 times earnings, a valuation Morgan Stanley analyst Rajeev Lalwani called "just too low," according to Barron's.
column8: Lalwani’s price target of $72 implies a 30 percent upside for Delta, which faces less competition in key markets than some of its peers, the paper reported.
column9: Goodyear, GT.O, trading at $27.01, 7.3 times earnings, is benefiting from car makers' shift toward trucks, for which tires are more profitable, and its earnings per share (EPS) is expected to rise at mid-teen percentages the next two years, the paper noted.
column10: Lincoln, LNC.N, whose earnings depend heavily on annuities models that have seen decline in recent years, closed Friday at $71.58.
column11: But its EPS is expected to rise 8 to 11 percent this year and each of the following two years, thanks in part to a strong stock market that has increased management fees, and an increased demand for savings products, Barron’s reported.
